channel.title: Best distribution
channel.description:
Ok so i need a little help. I've tried alot of ditributions and unfortunatly alot have failed. Coulod you help me out in helping me by guiding me to which distribution would work best. Thanks. Here are my specifications,
http://www.komplett.co.uk/k/ki.asp?sku=328233
The only difference is that i upgraded the hardrive to a 120gb western digital.
Also as far as im aware its AMD64.
Currently im using Mandriva, whicih at the moment is going pretty smooth. However i would like a distro that works very well with my laptop. Also Mandriva is currently taking my machine as i686 (Is this AMD64?) Thank you i will test just about any you recommend, or if any of you have the same laptop and have Linux on it please say so also :)
Thanks

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Slackware runs on toasters !

I’d recommend gentoo or arch linux, i use gentoo though.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @Rajae Rajae
item.description:
@Rajae wrote:

If it’s talking about the BIOS, try updating the BIOS and see if there is anything.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

The only problems ive had with both Ubuntu and Kubuntu are the PCI bios bugs, round 7 of them. After grubs loaded i get them, then a black screen for about 2-3mins then Kubuntu or Ubuntu boots. However the problem with the bios bugs is before the text displaying it has acted as if its zoomed in and displays the PCI bios bug as huge. Afterwards upon a reboot the text is still huge and just hangs… meaning i cant actually logon. At the moment im booting Kubuntu 7.10. At startup i used the debug option, and so far havn;t seen those pesky bios bug messages.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I would go with Kubuntu ( http://www.kubuntu.org/ ) I have been using it on my laptop and desktop for about 2 years, and I still love it.

I have to agree with you there. I have recently tried a few Linux distros (I’m totally new to Linux). I tried openSUSE and that was ok. I tried sabayon Linux and i didn’t really like it. I tried Ubuntu and kUbuntu and I liked them both. However I prefer KDE myself, which swayed me to kUbuntu. Software installation was a breeze and it doesn’t look like a dump. I’ve found in my experience that KDE has a lot more controls than GNOME but GNOME can be easier for beginners… Either way you go, you won’t be able to get away from having to use the terminal at some point.

My advice: try Ubuntu he you want GNOME and kUbuntu if you want KDE.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If the error messages cause no problems then they can be safely ignored, like my laptop on boot always prints some error like ‘cant set config for usb #1-2’ or something, but it doesn’t cause any problems so it is alright.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Thanks for the replies so far. Ok so i have installed Kubuntu and it works, picks up my drivers but theres just one problem. When i start it up (Kubuntu) it cos up with about 6 PCI Bios bugs invalid bridge or something and then it loads. However its just a black screen and takes about 3mins to load. Arch linux i have tried but it dosant pick up my sound drivers or wireless (or ethernet when i try connecting a cable) and the screen resolution is messed up but that’s easy to fix. Its the bios bug im concerned about its caused problems in the past.

*edit whoops i meant ark linux, arch no i havn’t tried.

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:3, topic:174397”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=234821.msg2004955#msg2004955 date=1200836034]
I would go with Kubuntu ( http://www.kubuntu.org/ ) I have been using it on my laptop and desktop for about 2 years, and I still love it. As far as AMD64, you do have a 64-bit (amd64) processor, but you can still run a 32-bit ( x86, or i686) operating system on it just fine, and in fact this is prefered by most people, because some applications and drivers don’t work well in a 64 bit system yet.
[/quote]
Apparently 32-bit causes “strain” on the processor or summthen gey.[/quote]

No, x86 has been in use since the early 90s, there is no extra strain on a CPU from it. Some applications are faster in 32bit, others in 64bit, this is generally blamed on the fact that the x86 compiler has been developed for 18 years, where as the amd64 compiler has only been in existence for a few years (4 or so maybe?)

Read full topic

item.title: Best distribution
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I would go with Kubuntu ( http://www.kubuntu.org/ ) I have been using it on my laptop and desktop for about 2 years, and I still love it. As far as AMD64, you do have a 64-bit (amd64) processor, but you can still run a 32-bit ( x86, or i686) operating system on it just fine, and in fact this is prefered by most people, because some applications and drivers don’t work well in a 64 bit system yet.

Apparently 32-bit causes “strain” on the processor or summthen gey.

Read full topic
